abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely, with significant
            impacts on institutional development. Nonetheless, the
            lessons suggest that: 1) although a long-term coconut
            development program has been prepared, there is still lack
            of consensus on the precise elements for the strategy of
            this program. Issues include the competition faced by
            coconut oil from substitutes in export markets, the
            agronomic constraint of shading, and a "holistic"
            approach in the preference to keep coconut as a secondary
            crop, or to diversify out of it to other profitable crops,
            or uses; 2) the private sector needs to be actively pursued,
            for experience shows that the private sector's contract
            services are more reliable, than attempting to establish
            separate public sector facilities; 3) innovative financing
            mechanisms need to be addressed, particularly, alternative
            cost-sharing arrangements should evolve to finance a
            long-term replanting program; 4) likewise, mechanisms to
            reduce planting costs should be explored, to help develop a
            market for coconut hybrid seedlings for replanting purposes.
            Experience suggests that hybrids may outperform tall
            coconuts, making those worth producing; and, 5) project
            delays undermined its benefits, thus project readiness at
            entry is critical for a timely implementation, which should
            include clear monitoring and evaluation practices.
